componenttext: Good morning. My name is Kat, and I will be your conference operator. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to ADP's Third Quarter Fiscal 2016 Earnings Call. I would like to inform you that this conference is being recorded [Operator Instructions] I will now turn the conference over to Ms. Sara Grilliot, Vice President, Investor Relations. Please go ahead.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Good morning, everyone. This is Sara Grilliot, ADP's Vice President, Investor Relations, and I'm here today with Carlos Rodriguez, ADP's President and Chief Executive Officer; and Jan Siegmund, ADP's Chief Financial Officer. Thank you for joini
componenttext:
Thank you. Good morning, everyone. This is Sara Grilliot, ADP's Vice President, Investor Relations, and I'm here today with Carlos Rodriguez, ADP's President and Chief Executive Officer; and Jan Siegmund, ADP's Chief Financial Officer. Thank you for joining us for our Third Quarter Fiscal 2016 Earnings Call and Webcast. During our call today, we will reference certain non-GAAP financial measures, which we believe to be useful to investors. A reconciliation of these non-GAAP financial measures to their comparable GAAP measures is included in our earnings release and in the supplemental slides on our Investor Relations website.
Before Carlos begins with a discussion of the quarter's results, I'd like to remind everyone that today's call will contain forward-looking statements that refer to future events and as such, involves some risk. We encourage you to review our filings with the SEC for additional information on risk factors that could cause actual results to differ materially from our current expectations.
So now let me turn the call over to Carlos.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Sara, and good morning, everyone. Thanks for joining our call and for your continued interest in ADP. This morning, we reported results for our third quarter of fiscal 2016, which included revenue growth of 7% or 9%, excluding the impacts of fo
componenttext:
Thank you, Sara, and good morning, everyone. Thanks for joining our call and for your continued interest in ADP. This morning, we reported results for our third quarter of fiscal 2016, which included revenue growth of 7% or 9%, excluding the impacts of foreign currency translation. In addition to this solid revenue growth, we continue to see strong demand for our solutions, which is evidenced by our new business bookings growth of 13%. While sales of additional human capital management modules that assist with the Affordable Care Act, or ACA compliance, continue to boost our performance, we were especially pleased to see balance growth contribution across our ACM portfolio. From further penetration of new application into our base, to growth in a number of clients using our Higher Touch HR outsourcing models, we are seeing continued traction for our technology solutions and our robust service offerings. 
During the quarter, ADP continues to focus on implementation of solutions that support ACA reporting requirements in the U.S. At the end of March, importers with 50 or more employees were required to send Form 1095-C to each of their employees, describing the health insurance available to them. This is the most significant employee tax filing form introduced by the U.S. government since the W-2, more than 70 years ago and is significantly more complex for the employer to deliver. More than 25,000 clients, ranging in size from 50 to 50,000 employees trusted ADP to assist them with ACA. As of March 31, ADP delivered nearly 10 million Form 1095-Cs to these client employees. This endeavor was no small task. To put it into perspective, ADP processed nearly 60 million W-2 forms for the 2015 tax year, a form we would have been producing for decades. The W-2 requires 1 system of record, the payroll system, and is therefore, significant be easier to produce than the 1095-C, which can require data from multiple sources. So as you may imagine, producing 10 million Form 1095-Cs in the first reporting year of this new regulations was demanding for us and required a strong partnership with our clients. 
This is another example of the breadth of our capabilities in the complex world of workforce compliance, and I am very proud of the work our teams have done and will continue to do to help these clients navigate the uncharted waters of ACA reporting. 
ADP's global capabilities also continue to be a differentiator for us. ADP first began offering global payroll services more than a decade ago, and we have continuously expanded our offering across Europe, the Middle East, Africa, Asia Pacific and the Americas. Last month, we announced the expansion of our capabilities to 7 additional locations, including Angola, Tanzania and Zambia. Now in a 111 countries around the globe, ADP is bringing our global client the benefits of integrated payroll solutions from a provider they trust. This ability to support the payroll compliance needs of global firms managing businesses in locales with constant changes in the legal and regulatory landscape is incredibly powerful and unrivaled in our industry. 
Now I'd like to give you an update on client retention. In the third quarter, ADP experienced a decline in retention of 30 basis points. We do believe the sequential improvement as a result of actions we've taken to strengthen our service capabilities. The talented professionals we've added to our service teams are now supporting our clients. And although we have an easier year-over-year comparison, we expect the client experience to continue to improve as these associates gain more experience. Aside from our clients interactions with ADP through service and implementation, a key component of the client experiences our technology. We believe that our strategic platforms deliver best-in-class HCM capabilities in each of the markets they serve. And clients on this platforms generally have higher retention rates than those on our mature technology. So we are continuing to focus on upgrading clients to our modern cloud solutions. As we've previously discussed, we intentionally slowed the pace of migrations in recent months, so we could best assist our clients with ACA compliance. With additional talent in place and the effort of ACA reporting beginning to slow, we intend to return to our migration pace to enable us to complete our midmarket upgrades through the latest version of Workforce Now by the end of fiscal year 2017, which is in line with our previous expectations. 
Upgrading clients for mature technology is an important element of our strategy and the right thing for our clients.
Positive external recognition further bolsters our confidence in our product and service offering. Earlier this quarter, we announced that Everest Group has once again named us a leader and star performer in its annual Everest Group Peak Matrix for Multiprocess HR Outsourcing Providers. The report cites the number of new deals, expanded global service delivery, success of our mobile solutions and the introduction of our analytics and big data solution called ADP Data Cloud as evidence of ADP's continued commitment to providing an enriched scope of solutions to our global clients. It's flattering when influencers recognize our strategic progress, but it's even more rewarding when clients do. I recently had the opportunity to spend time with many clients at our Annual ADP Meeting of the Minds Conference, which we just held in Washington, D.C. Each year, we use this opportunity to update our clients in our developments and share where we are headed while listening and learning more about their challenges. What's clear is that these are challenging times for payroll and HCM professionals. ACA, globalization, regulatory complexity, the fight for top talent and changing workforce dynamics are all having a profound impact on how HR is practiced. We've built our business to help clients through these challenges and many others. We are unique in our ability to deliver capabilities across the HCM spectrum, from recruitment through retirement for businesses of all sizes around the entire globe. This was on display at Meeting of the Minds, and the client response to our progress was gratifying. So with that, I'll turn the call over to Jan for further review of our third quarter results.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Carlos, and good morning, everyone. For the third quarter, ADP revenues grew 7% or 9% on a constant dollar basis. This solid revenue growth was driven by net new additions to our recurring revenue stream, including the impact of ACA-related rev
componenttext:
Thank you, Carlos, and good morning, everyone. For the third quarter, ADP revenues grew 7% or 9% on a constant dollar basis. This solid revenue growth was driven by net new additions to our recurring revenue stream, including the impact of ACA-related revenue, which began contributing to our growth in the third quarter. Earnings before interest and taxes, or EBIT, grew 9% or 10% on a constant dollar basis. This growth, while stronger than the first half of the fiscal year, continues to reflect additional costs related to selling expenses and incremental operational resources in support of new business sold. EBIT margin increased about 40 basis points compared to 24.4% in last year's third quarter. Diluted earnings per share grew 14% to $1.17, and reflected a lower effective tax rate and fewer shares outstanding compared with 1 year ago. In addition to delivering this solid operating performance, we have paid more than $700 million in dividends and returned more than $1 billion through share repurchases in the first 3 quarters of this fiscal year. 
In our employee services segment, revenues grew 5% for the quarter or 7% on a constant dollar basis. As Carlos discussed, client revenue retention decreased 30 basis points in the third quarter, and we remain focused on the actions that will improve this metric. Our same-store control in the U.S. grew 2.5%, and average client balances grew 2% compared to a year ago or 3% on a constant dollar basis. On a year-to-date basis, we have seen a relative slowing in our pace for control metric compared with the 3% growth last year, which we believe is consistent with the U.S. economy, reaching high employment levels. As a result of improving employment, we couldn't continue to see declines in states' unemployment insurance collections, which had a drag on client fund balances but a lesser rate than last year. This in combination with a week of Mona season and the impact from client losses experienced in the first half has put added pressure on the growth of our client fund balances for the quarter. 
Our business outside the U.S. continues to perform well, driven by the strength of our multinational solutions, which serve businesses of all size, from smaller midmarket clients to very large global corporations. 
Employee Services segment margin declined about 40 basis points for the third quarter. This decline resulted from the impact of planned investments made in operational resources to implement a strong volume of new business sold over the last few quarters. 
ADP's PO posted another quarter of strong performance, with third quarter revenue growth of 16% and growth in the average worksite employees of 14%. The PO also delivered a solid margin expansion of approximately 50 basis points in the third quarter, driven primarily by operating and selling efficiencies as we continue to see good execution and increased productivity. 
I'm pleased with the progress we have made. And we'll now give you an update on our expectations for fiscal year 2016.
For the fiscal year, ADP still expects revenue growth of about 7% or 9% on a constant dollar basis. As a reminder, this forecast includes almost 1 percentage point of expected pressure from the sale of the AdvancedMD business, which occurred towards the end of the first fiscal quarter. For the Employer Services segment, consistent with our prior forecast, revenue growth is anticipated to be 4% to 5% with 7% on a constant dollar basis. For the PEO, ADP is now anticipating revenue growth of about 17% compared with our prior forecast range of 16% to 18%. Our forecast for adjusted EBIT margin expansion of 50 basis points is unchanged. We are now expecting Employee Services margin expansion of about 50 basis points compared with our prior forecast of margin expansion of about 75 basis points. Margin in the PEO is now expected to expand up to 75 basis points compared with our prior forecast of about 50 basis points. We have narrowed our forecast for average time fund balances and are now expecting 3% growth or 4% on a constant dollar basis. We're also now expecting growth in client funds interest revenue to be about flat to last year compared with our prior forecast with increase of about $5 million. This is a result of the lower interest rate environment from the softening of the global economy. The total impact from the client funds extended investment strategy is still expected to be about flat compared to the $419 million in fiscal year 2015. The details of this forecast can be found in the supplemental slides on our Investor Relations website. Adjusted diluted earnings per share are now expected to grow about 12% from the $2.89 in fiscal year 2015 compared with our prior forecasted growth range of 11% to 13%. On a constant dollar basis, adjusted diluted earnings per share is expected to grow about 13% compared with our prior forecasted growth range of 12% to 14%. 
And with that, I now will turn it over to the operator to take your questions.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was just wondering if you could give us an update on the improved client retention rates that you saw in the quarter? Can you maybe talk about how much the rate of implementation slowed versus the prior quarter? You talked about the slowing there. And m
componenttext: I was just wondering if you could give us an update on the improved client retention rates that you saw in the quarter? Can you maybe talk about how much the rate of implementation slowed versus the prior quarter? You talked about the slowing there. And maybe give us an update on -- in the midmarket? Then you talked about 75k total clients and 45k on Workforce Now. Maybe an update on that 45k number please?

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll let Jan maybe put in a couple of stats also. But the -- when we -- the slowdown in implementation is really around migrations. Just to be clear. And I think after the first quarter, I think, we mentioned that we had began already the slowdown of some
componenttext: I'll let Jan maybe put in a couple of stats also. But the -- when we -- the slowdown in implementation is really around migrations. Just to be clear. And I think after the first quarter, I think, we mentioned that we had began already the slowdown of some of our migrations. Now there continue to be scheduled migrations that spilled over into the second quarter. So it's really towards the end of the second quarter, our fiscal second quarter, that we began to really try to focus more on stabilizing our service organization and also our ACA implementations, and, hence, this third leg that was putting pressure on us and the third leg of the stool, which is an important part of the strategy, but we felt like that  we could in the short-term, slow down or take pressure off of our selves is what we did around the slowdown in the migration. That's exactly what happened. To put it into perspective, the first quarter of the year, our migrations were more than double at the same rate of the previous year's first quarter. We still did some migrations here in the third quarter. But I would say it was at very, very low rates. And we had the desired impact, which has allowed us to focus on the other things that we had from a volume standpoint in ACA and also trying to redirect some of those resources to stabilizing our service environment. And so I think that was -- we did exactly what we had planned to do, and I think what we communicated. And I think we got the desired results. As I mentioned in the first and second quarter, there is no scientific way to know how much each of those 3 things was putting pressure individually on our retention and our client service experience. But we basically had one that we had very -- a lot of control over, which is migrations and we decided to slow it.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Maybe I'll add on the migration pace, Jim, for you. I think we migrated in March. We resumed the migrations, and I think it's in the range, so the number of clients on the latest version for Workforce Now has not changed materially, really, compared to ou
componenttext: Maybe I'll add on the migration pace, Jim, for you. I think we migrated in March. We resumed the migrations, and I think it's in the range, so the number of clients on the latest version for Workforce Now has not changed materially, really, compared to our last update. But we are still expecting to really complete the overall migrations in our midmarket on to Workforce Now to be completed by the end of fiscal year '17 as we had always planned for.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's very helpful color. And then maybe just a quick follow-up. Can you give us an update on the migrations you're seeing in the upmarket? Any rough metrics in terms of percentage of clients completed on that side?
componenttext: That's very helpful color. And then maybe just a quick follow-up. Can you give us an update on the migrations you're seeing in the upmarket? Any rough metrics in terms of percentage of clients completed on that side?

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think in the upmarket, it's probably more discussion around number of clients rather than percentages because I think it's just the nature of the business. And I think there we are, I think, moving ahead with plans in terms of similar strategy that we h
componenttext: I think in the upmarket, it's probably more discussion around number of clients rather than percentages because I think it's just the nature of the business. And I think there we are, I think, moving ahead with plans in terms of similar strategy that we had in a down market and in the midmarket, which is to get our clients onto our strategic platforms over time. But I think as we said over the last couple of quarters, I think it's probably not helpful. Again, these are very identical clients. Everybody knows who their names are. And most of our competitors what platforms they're on. We don't believe it's going to be useful for us to get into a lot of detail around our schedules and which platforms and which clients we're migrating. But you should take from the message that Jan and I just delivered on a previous question that you asked. We still believe this is the right thing to do and a slowdown in the midmarket was really just related to all the other moving parts that we  have not because we believe it's a wrong thing to do. So were still in the same strategy. I think it's consistent with prior quarters. We believe that the migrations and the upgrades in the upmarket are going to take longer that they have taken in the down market and in the mid-market. But we're comfortable with that because that's the different nature of the business in the upmarket.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes the line of Sara Gubins with Bank of America.
componenttext: Our next question comes the line of Sara Gubins with Bank of America.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's great to see the retention trend improving. Do you have any concern that it could get worse again if you ramp back up the migrations that have been slowed?
componenttext: It's great to see the retention trend improving. Do you have any concern that it could get worse again if you ramp back up the migrations that have been slowed?

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Obviously, like one of the -- as you know, new business bookings and retention are the 2 numbers that are not, "recurring revenues". So our business is actually very stable, very predictable. And those 2 numbers are also relatively stable and relatively p
componenttext: Obviously, like one of the -- as you know, new business bookings and retention are the 2 numbers that are not, "recurring revenues". So our business is actually very stable, very predictable. And those 2 numbers are also relatively stable and relatively predictable, but they have more variability in the rest of our numbers. So we never try to forecast quarter-to-quarter or future quarters on either new business bookings or client retention for that reason. So it's clearly a possibility. But it's not our plan. And so you can tell by our desire, or actually, our actions to reignite our migrations that we don't believe that, that will be the case. And we believe that medium and longer-term, it's the right thing to do, which I think would lead you to the conclusion that the other factors, like the high volumes of ACA and some of the service challenges we had around, which were related to ACA implementations and high volumes. The issues around inadequate service capabilities, I think, were also factors that contribute to our retention issues. And we don't think that it was only because of the client migrations. Otherwise, we wouldn't be a probably following a different path. So I think we're confident that it's still the right thing to do. As you know, we had been doing migrations for several years and had not had the same kinds of issues that we experienced over the past couple of quarters with regards to retention. So I think, again, no scientific evidence. But there are a lot of ways of triangulating where we think it's fundamentally the right thing to do. Went up higher tax rates for our modules in our retention rates right now are higher on a strategic platforms at our legacy platforms. There's a lot of reasons to point to the need and I think the advantages of continuing with the migration strategy.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And then turning to margins. The guidance suggest a pretty significant ramp year-over-year in the fourth quarter. Is that just the leverage of the hires that you've made? And are you now fully staffed up to higher migration in new sales? Or should
componenttext: Got it. And then turning to margins. The guidance suggest a pretty significant ramp year-over-year in the fourth quarter. Is that just the leverage of the hires that you've made? And are you now fully staffed up to higher migration in new sales? Or should we expect that to see come up more?

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think you're pointing out to one element. As now, revenue stream of incremental revenue gets really a full quarter. So we're going to see that. See that revenue -- that implicit revenue acceleration in the fourth quarter when you dissect our full y
componenttext: Yes. I think you're pointing out to one element. As now, revenue stream of incremental revenue gets really a full quarter. So we're going to see that. See that revenue -- that implicit revenue acceleration in the fourth quarter when you dissect our full year guidance that we confirmed. That will help. And secondly, the most important factor is in the fourth quarter, we are anticipating -- we have high investments of selling expense in last year's fourth quarter and easy roll over. So with a confirmation of our new business bookings growth of 12%, you can also see that we're not anticipating, mathematically, a blowout fourth quarter because of that difficult roll over that will help the margins.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I mean, I think that -- I think we've been -- I think communicating I think for several quarters, and I think it's still true that the products that we have that have the richest bundles, and it is not just PEO but it's also our midmarket what we call ASO
componenttext: I mean, I think that -- I think we've been -- I think communicating I think for several quarters, and I think it's still true that the products that we have that have the richest bundles, and it is not just PEO but it's also our midmarket what we call ASO, basically, our BPO HR outsourcing solutions. They are all growing faster than our core business. And they all have now, I think, very positive dynamics in terms of their margin. Not that you're ask about margins but they're also -- I think now what the size, all of them individually and collectively, where we're getting good contribution, I think, to lower margin -- assuming from a dollar standpoint and in many cases also, from a margin percent standpoint. So I think -- that's why we like our position in terms of where we are around starting with our richest bundles where it's really all inclusive in terms of full HCM bundle. The PEO is unique in a sense that it also us employment and provides health care and workers comp. Some of our other very rich bundles are also very, very comprehensive and growing variable and scaling very well. And we've been able to handle those volumes and have gotten good leverage on the margin side. And then as you  come down to our more traditional product, as we also committed a fair, whether it's in Advantage or Workforce Now or even in a down market, maybe attach rates continue to be better on new business than the penetration of our products in the base. So I think that also bodes very well for us, from a revenue growth standpoint and also from a margin leverage standpoint. So we're -- I think we're happy directionally with where we're going and where, frankly, the market is leading us, which is demand for the solutions, which is clearly high versus kind of the traditional simple standalone payroll solution. We do solve simple standalone payroll solutions. But I think the market is leading us in the direction of more comprehensive payroll solutions.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just going back. I think there was a question earlier about the market. Recognizing sales cycles are long, it's still early. But could you talk a little bit more about your experience thus far? And help us understand what the [indiscernible
componenttext: Okay. And then just going back. I think there was a question earlier about the market. Recognizing sales cycles are long, it's still early. And what are seeing success versus where some challenges as you approach that market?

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think the competitive dynamic in the upmarket is not terribly different than the competitive dynamic in the midmarket and in a down market, which is that it is competitive. And there is a lot of competition. But we're pretty happy with the progres
componenttext: Well, I think the competitive dynamic in the upmarket is not terribly different than the competitive dynamic in the midmarket and in a down market, which is that it is competitive. And there is a lot of competition. But we're pretty happy with the progress of our Advantage platforms there in terms of new sales. And we mentioned that, obviously, we're going to be methodical and careful in terms of our upgrade cycle in the upmarket, which I think fits naturally with the nature of that business anyway. So, I mean, as you know, we've been investing heavily in all of our products, including in the upmarket that also goes for Workforce Now with the midmarket. And we've made some significant investments over the year which is our downmarket platform. So it's hard to -- I know it's a very specific question about the upmarket. But it's hard for me to really single it out as having a different approach or a different strategy from the rest of our company. Because I don't think it is. I think we're on the same types of things.

componenttext: And maybe a if I add which will substantiate this -- the color in our new business bookings. We really try to say that we had a balance growth in the quarter and have experienced that actually for the last few quarters. And so the upmarket is participating in sales acceleration that we have seen for this year.

componenttext: This is actually Jay Hanna for Gary Bisbee. I was wondering if you could shed any light on why we haven't seen revenue acceleration just given a strong bookings growth over the previous several quarters? And particular this quarter as retention declined and we started the new calendar year?

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think as usual, we have -- you can probably, mathematically, as Jan has probably the math tip of his tongue. But I will tell you just interest and point, mathematically, you can tell that the fourth quarter -- we have a decent amount of visibility,
componenttext: Yes. I think as usual, we have -- you can probably, mathematically, as Jan has probably the math tip of his tongue. But I will tell you just interest and point, mathematically, you can tell that the fourth quarter -- we have a decent amount of visibility, given the nature of our business, as to what is happening quarter-to-quarter. And I think the fourth quarter, I think, again, when you exclude, which I think is the right way to do the comparison, you exclude the AdvancedMD comparable from the previous year. We don't have a lot of -- I think, in fact, our current forecast is to not have much of any foreign currency effect in the fourth quarter. I think you normalize for all those things, and we're actually pretty happy with what our fourth quarter revenue growth implies. And then the third quarter, I don't think it's -- it's not fair to say were disappointing because we're pretty happy. Whenever ADP's revenue growth incrementally moves up 0.5 to 1 percentage point, which again normalize for an normalize for currency, that's what happens. That makes us very happy. Because in a recurring revenue model, in order to accomplish that, you have to, as you just pointed out, you have to have strong new business starts, not just bookings. And you have to have either stable or improving retention. That's exactly what we got. There may have been a little calendar noise and a couple of other things in the third quarter that we don't see in the fourth quarter happening. And so we were actually pretty satisfied with kind of where we are. Assuming that all of these things kind of hold that we just communicated.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And if I can get one more in. I'm just wondering, given the strong bookings growth related to the AZA offering. And that begins to slow -- should we expect an overhang for that since that service offering kind of begin to fall off [indiscernible] to
componenttext: Okay. And if I can get one more in. I'm just wondering, given the strong bookings growth related to the AZA offering. And that begins to slow -- should we expect an overhang for that since that service offering kind of begin to fall off [indiscernible] to drop?

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think that, that was something I communicated in last quarter's call, which is, again, based on our kind of sense of the business, our experience and our knowledge, it's safe to assume that if we sold approximately half of the addressable market on ACA,
componenttext: I think that, that was something I communicated in last quarter's call, which is, again, based on our kind of sense of the business, our experience and our knowledge, it's safe to assume that if we sold approximately half of the addressable market on ACA, we believe there's still a lot of opportunity in our client base. But obviously now it's half the opportunity that we had in the previous year. What we don't know yet is how people will react in terms of demand because right now everybody is focused on getting the June deadline passed in terms of the employer portion of the employer, which is the 1094. And so  it is really a little early for us to know exactly how much ACA demand we will not have. And we've been very, very transparent and very clear that this provided tailwind. However, we've also been very clear that we would be satisfied and happy to communicate our sales results, both for the quarter and for the year-to-date, excluding ACA. And that communication would lead you to believe that excluding ACA, it will be the neighborhood of our long-term guidance around new business bookings. And so we believe this is incremental. We hope that we'll get more of it next year. But clearly, the mathematics are such that it's going to create -- I wouldn't call it a hangover or overhang. I would call it a very difficult compare that we as we get further along in the next couple of quarters, we'll be able to hopefully communicate a little bit more clearly in terms of what that exactly means when we provide guidance for the next fiscal year.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016

componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Rick Eskelsen with Wells Fargo.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016

componenttext: The question is just going back to margins. I was wondering if you could talk a little bit more in terms of the longer-term margin drivers with you altering the outlook for the 2 segments here on the margin side. Had anything changed longer-term and more fundamentally, like you see fewer opportunities in the Employer Services and more in the PEO on the margin front specifically?

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, we don't. I think that, again, when we have the kind of new business bookings growth that we have because of the way our P&L works around implementation expense and commissions and selling expense, it puts a lot of pressure. So honestly, I would proba
componenttext: No, we don't. I think that, again, when we have the kind of new business bookings growth that we have because of the way our P&L works around implementation expense and commissions and selling expense, it puts a lot of pressure. So honestly, I would probably say that I'm incredibly proud of the organization's ability to despite a very big ramp up of expenses, some of which was related, obviously, to ACA, both around new business bookings cost as well as implementation expense. I'm actually quite proud of the organization's ability to deliver on our  based on our forecast in the fourth quarter, will be some margin improvement, which still kind of in the neighborhood of our long-term guidance. So I think that leads me to believe that even though we still have a lot of investment to make in the business. I want to be very, very clear that we are managing all of the variables in our business, including the need to continue to invest in our technology, in our associates and a number of things. But if, in fact, as Jan said, if the fourth quarter, our new business bookings growth, because of the growth over the previous year is smaller, that takes pressure off us from a margin standpoint. The same would apply to next year if we're not providing guidance in terms of our new business bookings growth for the next year. But mathematically, if we get back into the long-term range of the new business bookings, that will also provide tailwind and help take pressure off of our margin. So again, I mean, I could go on for a long time in terms of our business model works. But we feel pretty good. In fact, this year, I think, would give us a high degree of encouragement. It was hard. And people worked very, very hard on controlling all controllable expenses in order to still deliver the kind of margin improvement that we are in the face of increased costs we had. But it just shows the power of the business model. And I think the ability of the company to leverage its revenue growth.

componenttext: I want to thank you for participating today. I just want to reiterate how proud I am of the organization's ability to get our solutions and lamented on ACA compliance. componenttext: Good morning. My name is Kat, and I will be your conference operator. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to ADP's Third Quarter Fiscal 2016 Earnings Call. Please go ahead.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Good morning, everyone. This is Sara Grilliot, ADP's Vice President, Investor Relations, and I'm here today with Carlos Rodriguez, ADP's President and Chief Executive Officer; and Jan Siegmund, ADP's Chief Financial Officer. Thank you for joini
componenttext:
Thank you. Good morning, everyone. This is Sara Grilliot, ADP's Vice President, Investor Relations, and I'm here today with Carlos Rodriguez, ADP's President and Chief Executive Officer; and Jan Siegmund, ADP's Chief Financial Officer. Thank you for joining us for our third quarter fiscal 2016 earnings call and webcast. During our call today, we will reference certain non-GAAP financial measures, which we believe to be useful to investors. A reconciliation of these non-GAAP financial measures to their comparable GAAP measures is included in our earnings release and in the supplemental slides on our Investor Relations website.
Before Carlos begins with a discussion of the quarter's results, I'd like to remind everyone that today's call will contain forward-looking statements that refer to future events and as such, involves some risk. We encourage you to review our filings with the SEC for additional information on risk factors that could cause actual results to differ materially from our current expectations.
So now, let me turn the call over to Carlos.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Sara, and good morning, everyone. Thanks for joining our call and for your continued interest in ADP. This morning, we reported results for our third quarter of fiscal 2016, which included revenue growth of 7% or 9%, excluding the impacts of fo
componenttext:
Thank you, Sara, and good morning, everyone. Thanks for joining our call and for your continued interest in ADP. This morning, we reported results for our third quarter of fiscal 2016, which included revenue growth of 7% or 9%, excluding the impacts of foreign currency translation. In addition to this solid revenue growth, we continue to see strong demand for our solutions, which is evidenced by our new business bookings growth of 13%. While sales of additional human capital management modules that assist with the Affordable Care Act, or ACA, compliance continue to boost our performance, we are especially pleased to see balanced growth contribution across our HCM portfolio. From further penetration of new applications into our base to growth in the number of clients choosing our higher-touch HR outsourcing models, we are seeing continued traction for our technology solutions and our robust service offerings. 
During the quarter, ADP continued to focus on implementation of solutions that support ACA reporting requirements in the U.S. At the end of March, employers with 50 or more employees were required to send Form 1095-C to each of their employees, describing the health insurance available to them. This is the most significant employee tax filing form introduced by the U.S. government since the W2 more than 7 years ago, and it is significantly more complex for the employer to deliver. More than 25,000 clients, ranging in size from 50 to 50,000 employees trusted ADP to assist them with ACA. As of March 31, ADP delivered nearly 10 million Form 1095-Cs to these client employees. This endeavor was no small task. To put it in perspective, ADP processed nearly 60 million W2 forms for the 2015 tax year, a form we have been producing for decades. The W2 requires one system of record, the payroll system, and is therefore, significantly easier to produce than the 1095-C, which can require data from multiple sources. So as you may imagine, producing 10 million Form 1095-Cs in the first reporting year of these new regulations was demanding for us and required a strong partnership with our clients. 
This is another example of the breadth of our capabilities in the complex world of workforce compliance, and I am very proud of the work our teams have done and will continue to do to help these clients navigate the uncharted waters of ACA reporting. 
ADP's global capabilities also continue to be a differentiator for us. ADP first began offering global payroll services more than a decade ago, and we have continuously expanded our offering across Europe, the Middle East, Africa, Asia Pacific and the Americas. Last month, we announced the expansion of our capabilities to 7 additional locations, including Angola, Tanzania and Zambia. Now in 111 countries around the globe, ADP is bringing our global client the benefits of integrated payroll solutions from a provider they trust. This ability to support the payroll compliance needs of global firms managing businesses in locales with constant changes in the legal and regulatory landscape is incredibly powerful and unrivaled in our industry. 
Now I'd like to give you an update on client retention. In the third quarter, ADP experienced a decline in retention of 30 basis points. We do believe the sequential improvement is a result of actions we've taken to strengthen our service capabilities. The talented professionals we've added to our service teams are now supporting our clients. And although we have an easier year-over-year comparison, we expect the client experience to continue to improve as these associates gain more experience. Aside from our clients interactions with ADP through service and implementation, a key component of the client experience is our technology. We believe that our strategic platforms deliver best-in-class HCM capabilities in each of the markets they serve. And clients on this platforms generally have higher retention rates than those on our matured technology. So we are continuing to focus on upgrading clients to our modern cloud solutions. As we've previously discussed, we intentionally slowed the pace of migrations in recent months, so we could best assist our clients with ACA compliance. With additional talent in place and the effort of ACA reporting beginning to slow, we intend to return to a migration pace that will enable us to complete our mid-market upgrades to the latest version of Workforce Now by the end of fiscal year 2017, which is in line with our previous expectations. 
Upgrading clients for mature technology is an important element of our strategy and the right thing for our clients.
Positive external recognition further bolsters our confidence in our product and service offering. Earlier this quarter, we announced that Everest Group has once again named us a leader and star performer in its annual Everest Group Peak Matrix for Multi-Process HR Outsourcing Providers. The report cites the number of new deals, expanded global service delivery, success of our mobile solutions and the introduction of our analytics and big data solution called ADP DataCloud as evidence of ADP's continued commitment to providing an enriched scope of solutions to our global clients. It's flattering when influencers recognize our strategic progress, but it's even more rewarding when clients do. I recently had the opportunity to spend time with many clients at our Annual ADP Meeting of the Minds Conference, which we just held in Washington, D.C. Each year, we use this opportunity to update our clients on our developments and share where we are headed, while listening and learning more about their challenges. What's clear is that these are challenging times for payroll and HCM professionals. ACA, globalization, regulatory complexity, their fight for top talent and changing workforce dynamics are all having a profound impact on how HR is practiced. We've built our business to help clients through these challenges and many others. We are unique in our ability to deliver capabilities across the HCM spectrum, from recruitment through retirement for businesses of all sizes around the entire globe. This was on display at Meeting of the Minds, and the client response to our progress was gratifying. 
So with that, I'll turn the call over to Jan for a further review of our third quarter results.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Carlos, and good morning, everyone. For the third quarter, ADP revenues grew 7% or 9% on a constant dollar basis. This solid revenue growth was driven by net new additions to our recurring revenue stream, including the impact of ACA-related rev
componenttext:
Thank you, Carlos, and good morning, everyone. For the third quarter, ADP revenues grew 7% or 9% on a constant dollar basis. This solid revenue growth was driven by net new additions to our recurring revenue stream, including the impact of ACA-related revenue, which began contributing to our growth in the third quarter. Earnings before interest and taxes, or EBIT, grew 9% or 10% on a constant dollar basis. This growth, while stronger than the first half of the fiscal year, continues to reflect additional costs related to selling expenses and incremental operational resources in support of new business sold. EBIT margin increased about 40 basis points compared to 24.4% in last year's third quarter. Diluted earnings per share grew 14% to $1.17, and reflected a lower effective tax rate and fewer shares outstanding compared with a year ago. In addition to delivering this solid operating performance, we have paid more than $700 million in dividends and returned more than $1 billion through share repurchases in the first 3 quarters of this fiscal year. 
In our Employer Services segment, revenues grew 5% for the quarter or 7% on a constant dollar basis. As Carlos discussed, client revenue retention decreased 30 basis points in the third quarter, and we remain focused on actions that will improve this metric. Our same-store pay per control in the U.S. grew 2.5%, and average client fund balances grew 2% compared to a year ago or 3% on a constant dollar basis. On a year-to-date basis, we have seen a relative slowing in our pays per control metric compared with the 3% growth last year, which we believe is consistent with the U.S. economy reaching high employment levels. As a result of improving employment, we couldn't continue to see declines in state unemployment insurance collections, which have had a drag on client fund balances, but at a lesser rate than last year. This in combination with a week of bonus season and the impact from client losses experienced in the first half has put added pressure on the growth of our client fund balances for the quarter. 
Our business outside the U.S. continues to perform well, driven by the strength of our multinational solutions, which serve businesses of all size, from smaller mid-market clients to very large global corporations. 
Employer Services segment margin declined about 40 basis points for the third quarter. This decline resulted from the impact of planned investments made in operational resources to implement a strong volume of new business sold over the last few quarters. 
ADP's PEO posted another quarter of strong performance, with third quarter revenue growth of 16% and growth in the average worksite employees of 14%. The PEO also delivered solid margin expansion of approximately 50 basis points in the third quarter, driven primarily by operating and selling efficiencies, as we continue to see good execution and increased productivity. 
I'm pleased with the progress we have made, and we'll now give you an update on our expectations for fiscal year 2016.
For the fiscal year, ADP still expects revenue growth of about 7% or 9% on a constant dollar basis. As a reminder, this forecast includes almost 1 percentage point of expected pressure from the sale of the AdvancedMD business, which occurred towards the end of the first fiscal quarter. For the Employer Services segment, consistent with our prior forecast, revenue growth is anticipated to be 4% to 5% with 7% on a constant dollar basis. For the PEO, ADP is now anticipating revenue growth of about 17% compared with our prior forecast range of 16% to 18%. Our forecast for adjusted EBIT margin expansion of 50 basis points is unchanged. We are now expecting Employer Services margin expansion of about 50 basis points compared with our prior forecast of margin expansion of about 75 basis points. Margin in the PEO is now expected to expand up to 75 basis points compared with our prior forecast of about 50 basis points. We have narrowed our forecast for average client fund balances and are now expecting 3% growth or 4% on a constant dollar basis. 
We're also now expecting growth in client funds interest revenue to be about flat to last year compared with our prior forecasted increase of up to $5 million. This is a result of the lower interest rate environment from the softening of the global economy. The total impact from the client funds extended investment strategy is still expected to be about flat compared to the $419 million in fiscal year 2015. The details of this forecast can be found in the supplemental slides on our Investor Relations website. 
Adjusted diluted earnings per share are now expected to grow about 12% from the $2.89 in fiscal year 2015 compared with our prior forecasted growth range of 11% to 13%. On a constant dollar basis, adjusted diluted earnings per share is expected to grow about 13% compared with our prior forecasted growth range of 12% to 14%. 
And with that, I now will turn it over to the operator to take your questions.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes the line of Jim Schneider with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes the line of Jim Schneider with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was wondering if you can give us an update on the improved client retention rates that you saw in the quarter. Can you maybe talk about how much the rate of implementation slowed versus the prior quarter? You talked about the slowing there. And maybe gi
componenttext: I was wondering if you can give us an update on the improved client retention rates that you saw in the quarter. Can you maybe talk about how much the rate of implementation slowed versus the prior quarter? You talked about the slowing there. And maybe give us an update on -- in the mid-market? I think you talked about 75k total clients and 45k on Workforce Now. Maybe an update on that 45k number, please?

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. I'll let Jan maybe put in a couple of stats also, but the -- when we -- the slowdown in implementation was really around migrations, just to be clear. And I think after the first quarter, I think we mentioned that we had begun already to slowdown so
componenttext: Sure. I'll let Jan maybe put in a couple of stats also, but the -- when we -- the slowdown in implementation was really around migrations, just to be clear. And I think after the first quarter, I think we mentioned that we had begun already to slowdown some of our migrations. Now there continued to be some scheduled migrations that spilled over into the second quarter. So it was really towards the end of the second quarter or fiscal second quarter that we began to really try to focus more on stabilizing our service organization and also our ACA implementations, and hence, this third leg that was putting pressure on us, and the third leg of the stool, which is an important part of our strategy, but we felt like we could, in the short-term, slow down or take pressure off of our selves is what we did around the slowdown in the migration. That's exactly what happened. To put it in perspective, the first quarter of the year, our migrations were more than double at the same rate of the previous year's first quarter. We still did some migrations here in the third quarter. But I would say it was very, very low rates, and we had -- we got the desired impact, which has allowed us to focus on the other things that we had from a volume standpoint on ACA and also trying to redirect some of those resources to stabilizing our service environment. And so I think that was -- we did exactly what we had planned to do, and I think what we communicated. And I think we got the desired results. As I mentioned in the first and second quarter, there is no scientific way to know how much each of those 3 things was putting pressure individually on our retention and our client service experience, but we basically had one that we had very -- a lot of control over, which is migrations, and we decided to slow it.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Maybe I'll add on the migration pace, Jim, for you. I think we migrated in March. We resumed the migrations, and I think it's in the 1,000 range. So the number of clients on the latest version for Workforce Now has not changed materially, really, compared
componenttext: Maybe I'll add on the migration pace, Jim, for you. I think we migrated in March. We resumed the migrations, and I think it's in the 1,000 range. So the number of clients on the latest version for Workforce Now has not changed materially, really, compared to our last update, but we are still expecting to really complete the overall migrations in our mid-market on to Workforce Now to be completed by the end of fiscal year '17 as we had always planned for.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's very helpful color. And then maybe just a quick follow-up. Can you give us an update on the migrations you're seeing in the upmarket? Any rough metrics in terms of percentage of clients completed on that side?
componenttext: That's very helpful color. And then maybe just a quick follow-up. Can you give us an update on the migrations you're seeing in the upmarket? Any rough metrics in terms of percentage of clients completed on that side?

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think in the upmarket, it's probably more discussion around number of clients rather than percentages, because I think it's just the nature of the business. And I think there we are, I think, moving ahead with plans in terms of a similar strategy of wha
componenttext: I think in the upmarket, it's probably more discussion around number of clients rather than percentages, because I think it's just the nature of the business. And I think there we are, I think, moving ahead with plans in terms of a similar strategy of what we had in the downmarket and in the mid-market, which is to get our clients onto our strategic platforms over time. But I think as we said over the last couple of quarters, I think it's probably not helpful. And given that these are very identifiable clients, everyone knows who their names are and most of our competitors know what platforms they're on. We don't believe that it's going to be fruitful and useful for us to get into a lot of detail around our schedules and which platforms and which clients we're migrating. But you should take from the message that Jan and I just delivered on the previous question that you asked that we still believe this is the right thing to do and the slowdown in the mid-market was really just related to all the other moving parts that we had, not because we believe it's the wrong thing to do. So we're still on the same strategy. It's, I think, consistent with prior quarters. We believe that the migrations and the upgrades in the upmarket are going to take longer that they have taken in the downmarket and in the mid-market, but we're comfortable with that, because that's just a different nature of the business in the upmarket.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes the line of Sara Gubins with Bank of America.
componenttext: Our next question comes the line of Sara Gubins with Bank of America.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's great to see the retention trend improving. Do you have any concern that it could get worse again if you ramp back up the migrations that have been slowed?
componenttext: It's great to see the retention trend improving. Do you have any concern that it could get worse again if you ramp back up the migrations that have been slowed?

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Obviously, like one of the -- as you know, new business bookings and retention are the 2 numbers that are not "recurring revenues." Our business model is actually very stable, very predictable. And those 2 numbers are also relatively stable and relatively
componenttext: Obviously, like one of the -- as you know, new business bookings and retention are the 2 numbers that are not "recurring revenues." Our business model is actually very stable, very predictable. And those 2 numbers are also relatively stable and relatively predictable, but they have more variability on the rest of our numbers. So we never try to forecast quarter-to-quarter or future quarters on either new business bookings or client retention for that reason. So it's clearly a possibility, but it's not our plan. And so you can tell by our desire, or actually our actions to reignite our migrations that we don't believe that, that will be the case, and we believe that medium and longer-term, it's the right thing to do, which I think would lead you to the conclusion that the other factors like the high volumes of ACA and some of the service challenges we had around -- which were related to ACA implementations and high volumes. Their issues around inadequate service capabilities, I think, were also factors that contributed to our retention issues. And we don't think that it was only because of the client migrations. Otherwise, we obviously wouldn't be -- we would be probably following a different path. So I think we're confident that it's still the right thing to do. As you know, we had been doing migrations for several years and had not had the same kinds of issues that we experienced over the past couple of quarters with regards to retention. So I think, again, no scientific evidence, but I think we have a lot of ways of triangulating to the point where we think it's fundamentally the right thing to do. We ended up having more attach -- higher attach rates for our HCA modules. Our retention rates right now are higher on our strategic platforms and our legacy platforms. There's a lot of reasons that point to the need, and I think the advantages of continuing with the migration strategy.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And then turning to margins, the ES guidance on margins suggest a pretty significant ramp year-over-year in the fourth quarter. Is that just the leverage at hires that you've made? And are you now fully staffed up to higher migration in new sales
componenttext: Got it. And then turning to margins, the ES guidance on margins suggest a pretty significant ramp year-over-year in the fourth quarter. Is that just the leverage at hires that you've made? And are you now fully staffed up to higher migration in new sales or should we expect to see that come up more?

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think you're pointing out to one element. As now, the revenue stream of the incremental revenues gets really a full quarter, so we'll see that -- see that revenue. Implicit revenue acceleration in the fourth quarter when you dissect our full year g
componenttext: Yes. I think you're pointing out to one element. As now, the revenue stream of the incremental revenues gets really a full quarter, so we'll see that -- see that revenue. Implicit revenue acceleration in the fourth quarter when you dissect our full year guidance that we confirmed. That will help. And secondly, the most important factor is, in fourth quarter, we are anticipating -- we had a -- have high investments of selling expense in the last year's fourth quarter and an easier roll over. So with the confirmation of our new business bookings growth of 12%, you can also see that we're not anticipating, mathematically, a blowout fourth quarter because of that difficult roll over and that will help on the margin.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of David Grossman with Stifel.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of David Grossman with Stifel.

componenttext: I was wondering if you could just talk a little bit about just the character of the business and how it's evolving? So given that the client is mixing the bundled solutions, specifically ACO and PEO since they're presumably growing at faster rates, should we be thinking any differently about how those scales -- excuse me, how those clients scale differently than the traditional payroll business route over time?

componenttext: Well, I was thinking more in terms of revenue growth, but you could include margin as well. But I was just thinking that because they're buying more, that is, say, for example, there are pays per control increased, this business may scale a little bit differently than the traditional payroll businesses go ahead.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I mean, I think that -- I think we've been -- I think communicating, I think, for several quarters, and I think it's still true that the products that we have that have the richest bundles, and it is not just PEO, but it's also our mid-market what we call
componenttext: I mean, I think that -- I think we've been -- I think communicating, I think, for several quarters, and I think it's still true that the products that we have that have the richest bundles, and it is not just PEO, but it's also our mid-market what we call ASO and -- basically, our BPO HR outsourcing solutions. They are all growing faster than our core business. And they all have now, I think, very positive dynamics in terms of their margin. Not that you were asking specifically about margins, but they're also -- I think now at a size, all of them individually and collectively, where we're getting good contribution, I think, to lower margin from a -- certainly from a dollar standpoint and in many cases also, from a margin percent standpoint. So I think we're -- that's why we like our position in terms of where we are around starting with our richest bundles where -- it's really all inclusive in terms of a full HCM bundle. The PEO is unique in the sense that it also has co-employment and provides health care and workers comp. But some of our other very rich bundles also are very, very comprehensive and growing variable, bustling and scaling very well. And we've been able to handle those volumes and have gotten good leverage on the margin side. And then as you come down to our more traditional products, as we've also communicated there, whether it's in Vantage or in Workforce Now or even in the downmarket, the attach rates continue to be better on new business than the penetration of our products in the base. So I think that also bodes very well for us from a revenue growth standpoint and also from a margin leverage standpoint. So we're -- I think we're happy directionally with the -- where we're going and where, frankly, the market is leading us, which is demand for these solutions, which is clearly high versus kind of the traditional simple stand-alone payroll solution. We do sell simple stand-alone payroll solutions, but I think the market is leading us in the direction of more comprehensive solutions.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just going back, I think there was a question earlier about the upmarket and -- recognizing sales cycles are long, it's still early. But could you talk a little bit more about your experience thus far and just help us understand better what
componenttext: Okay. And then just going back, I think there was a question earlier about the upmarket and -- recognizing sales cycles are long, it's still early. But could you talk a little bit more about your experience thus far and just help us understand better what the concerted dynamic is there? Where are you seeing success versus where there are some challenges as you approach that market?

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think the competitive dynamic in the upmarket is not terribly different than the competitive dynamic in the mid-market and in the downmarket, which is that it's competitive and there is a lot of competition, but we're pretty happy with the progres
componenttext: Well, I think the competitive dynamic in the upmarket is not terribly different than the competitive dynamic in the mid-market and in the downmarket, which is that it's competitive and there is a lot of competition, but we're pretty happy with the progress of our Vantage platforms there in terms of new sales. And we mentioned that, obviously, we're going to be methodical and careful in terms of our upgrade cycle in the upmarket, which I think fits naturally with the nature of that business anyway. So -- I mean, you -- as you know, we've been investing heavily in all of our products, including in the upmarket, but that also goes for Workforce Now in the mid-market. And we've made some significant investments over the years in run, which is our downmarket platform. So it's hard to -- I know you -- it sort of sprays specific question about the upmarket, but it's hard for me to really single it out as having a different approach or a different strategy from the rest of our company because I don't think it is. I think we're on the same types of things.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And may be if I add some, which will substantiate this with the color on our new business bookings. We really try to say that we had a balanced growth in the quarter and have experienced that actually for the last few quarters. And so the upmarket is part
componenttext: And may be if I add some, which will substantiate this with the color on our new business bookings. We really try to say that we had a balanced growth in the quarter and have experienced that actually for the last few quarters. And so the upmarket is participating in sales acceleration that we have seen for this year.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And next question comes from the line of Gary Bisbee with RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: And next question comes from the line of Gary Bisbee with RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is actually Jay Hanna on the line for Gary today. I was wondering if you could shed any light on why we haven't seen more revenue acceleration just given the strong bookings growth over the previous several quarters, in particular this quarter, as re
componenttext: This is actually Jay Hanna on the line for Gary today. I was wondering if you could shed any light on why we haven't seen more revenue acceleration just given the strong bookings growth over the previous several quarters, in particular this quarter, as retention declined and we started the new calendar year?

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think as usual, we have -- you can probably, mathematically, as Jan is -- probably has the math at the tip of his tongue, but I would tell you that just from an overall big picture standpoint, mathematically, you can tell that the fourth quarter --
componenttext: Yes. I think as usual, we have -- you can probably, mathematically, as Jan is -- probably has the math at the tip of his tongue, but I would tell you that just from an overall big picture standpoint, mathematically, you can tell that the fourth quarter -- we have a decent amount of visibility, given the nature of our business, as to what is happening quarter-to-quarter. And I think the fourth quarter, I think, again, when you exclude, which I think is the right way to do the comparison, you exclude the AdvancedMD comparable from the previous year, we don't have a lot of -- I think, in fact, our current forecast is to not have much if any foreign currency effect in the fourth quarter. I think you normalize for all those things, and we're actually pretty happy with what our fourth quarter revenue growth implies. And then the third quarter, I don't think we were -- it's not fair to say we are disappointing, because we're pretty happy like whenever ADP's revenue growth incrementally moves up 0.5 to 1 percentage point, which is when you -- again, you normalize for AdvancedMD and you normalize for currency, that's what happened. That makes us very happy, because in a recurring revenue model, in order to accomplish that, you have to, as you just pointed out, you have to have strong new business starts, not just bookings. And you have to have either stable or improving retention. That's exactly what we got. There may have been a little calendar noise and a couple of other things in the third quarter that we don't see in the fourth quarter happening. And so we were actually pretty satisfied with kind of where we are. Assuming that all of these things kind of hold that we've just communicated.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And if I can get one more in. I was just wondering given the strong bookings growth related to the ACA offering. And that begins to slow -- should we expect an overhang from that as that service offering kind of begins to fall off [indiscernible] be
componenttext: Okay. And if I can get one more in. I was just wondering given the strong bookings growth related to the ACA offering. And that begins to slow -- should we expect an overhang from that as that service offering kind of begins to fall off [indiscernible] begins to drop?

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think that, that was something that I communicated in last quarter's call, which is, again, based on our kind of sense of the business, our experience and our knowledge, it's safe to assume that if we've sold approximately half of the addressable market
componenttext: I think that, that was something that I communicated in last quarter's call, which is, again, based on our kind of sense of the business, our experience and our knowledge, it's safe to assume that if we've sold approximately half of the addressable market on ACA, we believe there's still a lot of opportunity in our client base, but obviously now it's half the opportunity that we had in the previous year. What we don't know yet is how people will react in terms of demand because right now everybody is focused on getting the June deadline pass them in terms of the employer portion of the reporting, which is the 1094. And so there -- it's really a little early for us to know exactly how much ACA demand we will or we will not have. And we've been very, very transparent and very clear that this provided tailwind. However, we've also been very clear that we would be satisfied and happy to communicate our sales results, both for the quarter and for the year-to-date excluding ACA. And that communication would lead you to believe that excluding ACA, it would be in the neighborhood of our long-term guidance around new business bookings. And so we believe this has been incremental. We hope we will get more of it next year. But clearly, the mathematics are such that it's going to create, I wouldn't call it a hangover or an overhang, I would call it a very difficult compare that we -- as we get further along in the next couple of quarters, we'll be able to hopefully communicate a little bit more clearly in terms of what that exactly means when we provide guidance for the next fiscal year.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Rick Eskelsen with Wells Fargo.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Rick Eskelsen with Wells Fargo.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: The question is just going back to margins. I was wondering if you could talk a little bit more about sort of the longer-term margin drivers with you altering the outlook for the 2 segments here on the margin side. Has anything changed longer-term and mor
componenttext: The question is just going back to margins. I was wondering if you could talk a little bit more about sort of the longer-term margin drivers with you altering the outlook for the 2 segments here on the margin side. Has anything changed longer-term and more fundamentally, like do you see fewer opportunities in the Employer Services and more in the PEO on the margin front, specifically?

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, we don't. I think that, again, when we have the kind of new business bookings growth that we have because of the way our P&L works around implementation expense and commissions and selling expense, it puts a lot of pressure. So honestly, I would proba
componenttext: No, we don't. I think that, again, when we have the kind of new business bookings growth that we have because of the way our P&L works around implementation expense and commissions and selling expense, it puts a lot of pressure. So honestly, I would probably say that I'm incredibly proud of the organization's ability to despite a very big ramp up of expenses, some of which was related, obviously, to ACA, both around new business bookings cost as well as implementation expense, I'm actually quite proud of the organization's ability to deliver on our -- based on our forecast for the fourth quarter, will be some margin improvement, but it's still kind of in the neighborhood of our long-term guidance. So I think that leads me to believe that even though we still have a lot of investment we want to make in the business, I want to be very, very clear that we are managing all of the variables in our business, including the need to continue to invest in our technology, in our associates and a number of things. But if, in fact, as Jan said, if the fourth quarter, our new business bookings growth, because of the growth over the previous year, is smaller, that takes pressure off of us from a margin standpoint. The same would apply to next year if we're not providing guidance in terms of our new business bookings growth for the next year. But mathematically, if we get back into the long-term range of our new business bookings, that will also provide tailwind and help take pressure off of our margin. So again, we're getting -- I mean, I could go on for a long time in terms of how our business model works, but we feel pretty good. In fact, this year, I think would give us a high degree of encouragement. It was hard. And people worked very, very hard on controlling all controllable expenses in order to still deliver the kind of margin improvement. We are in the face of the increased costs we had, but it just shows the power of the business model, and I think the ability of the company to leverage its revenue growth.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Then just following up just on the staffing up you did in this past quarter. Just curious if you are fully staffed or completely right staffed for the migrations in the effort or if there's still more incremental hiring to do?
componenttext: Then just following up just on the staffing up you did in this past quarter. Just curious if you are fully staffed or completely right staffed for the migrations in the effort or if there's still more incremental hiring to do?

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think one of the comments I made in my opening statement was around the -- what we're looking forward to is we have added a lot of additional resources that are in the process of ramping up. In other words, going through training. And frankly, it's not
componenttext: I think one of the comments I made in my opening statement was around the -- what we're looking forward to is we have added a lot of additional resources that are in the process of ramping up. In other words, going through training. And frankly, it's not just about training because that's a relatively short process, but it's just the way it works probably in most companies that, obviously, as a person becomes more tenured, they become more effective and more productive. And so we do expect to have continued help from the resources that we've added. But in terms of headcount, in terms of FTE headcount, we believe we are fully staffed and that we are where we wanted to be at this point.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016

componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Danyal Hussain with Morgan Stanley.
