headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning. My name is Andrew, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to ADP's Fourth Quarter Fiscal 2016 Earnings Call. I would like to inform you that this conference is being recorded. [Operat
componenttext:
Good morning. My name is Andrew, and I will be your conference operator today. 
At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to ADP's Fourth Quarter Fiscal 2016 Earnings Call. 
I would like to inform you that this conference is being recorded. [Operator Instructions] 
I will now turn the conference over to Ms. Sara Grilliot, Vice President of Investor Relations. Please go ahead.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Good morning, everyone. This is Sara Grilliot, ADP's Vice President, Investor Relations, and I'm here today with Carlos Rodriguez, ADP's President and Chief Executive Officer; and  Jan Siegmund, ADP's Chief Financial Officer. Thank you for jo
componenttext:
Thank you. Good morning, everyone. This is Sara Grilliot, ADP's Vice President, Investor Relations, and I'm here today with Carlos Rodriguez, ADP's President and Chief Executive Officer; and  Jan Siegmund, ADP's Chief Financial Officer. 
Thank you for joining us for our fourth quarter fiscal 2016 earnings call and webcast. 
Before we begin, you might have noticed in the slide presentation posted on our website that we included the detail of our client funds available for sale portfolios as of June 30, 2016, which showed the embedded book yield of the portfolio by year-end maturity. This chart is in the appendix of the presentation and is provided for your information. 
During our call today, we will reference certain non-GAAP financial measures, which we believe to be useful to investors. A reconciliation of these non-GAAP financial measures to their comparable GAAP measures is included in our earnings release and in the supplemental slides on our Investor Relations website. 
Before Carlos begins I'd like to remind everyone that today's call will contain forward-looking statements that refer to future events and as such, involve some risk. We encourage you to review our filings with the SEC for additional information on risk factors that could cause actual results to differ materially from our current expectations. 
Now let me turn the call over to Carlos.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Sara, and good morning, everyone. Thanks for joining our call and for your continued interest in ADP. This morning, we reported solid results for the fourth quarter and full fiscal year 2016 with revenue up 8% for the quarter and 7% for the y
componenttext:
Thank you, Sara, and good morning, everyone. Thanks for joining our call and for your continued interest in ADP. 
This morning, we reported solid results for the fourth quarter and full fiscal year 2016 with revenue up 8% for the quarter and 7% for the year. Excluding the impact of foreign currency translation, fiscal 2016 revenue grew 8%. 
Please keep in mind that our 8% growth in fiscal 2016 was negatively impacted by about 1 percentage point from the sale of our AdvancedMD business, which occurred at the end of the first fiscal quarter. 
In addition to the solid fiscal 2016 revenue growth, I'm very pleased with the robust new business bookings results we experienced during fiscal 2016, posting 12% growth for the year. This represents $1.75 billion in new recurring revenue generated by our sales force during the fiscal year. 
Strong sales of Human Capital Management modules that assist clients in compliance with Affordable Care Act contributed meaningfully to the out performance we have seen in new business bookings for the past 2 fiscal years. 
This important regulatory change impacted the HCM industry in material ways. ADP responded well and sold our ACA compliance solutions to about half of our addressable base in a relatively short period of time. Because of this very strong recent performance and the resulting difficult compare, we expect fiscal 2017 new business bookings to grow 4% to 6% from the $1.75 billion sold in fiscal 2016. 
If achieved, this will result in a 3-year compounded annual growth rate of 9%, which is within our long term expected range of 8% to 10%. 
Fiscal 2016 was an exciting year that showcased ADP's agility as we continue to adapt to the dynamic needs of our clients. When we look back at our progress, it's clear that the long-term trends we see with respect to the changing nature of how work is done, the increasing complexity of regulatory compliance, the trend toward harnessing the power of big data in HR and the need to work seamlessly across geographic borders are all having positive impacts on our success. We've responded to these trends in many ways during the year. 
For example, across the portfolio, we've dramatically improved the user experience of our clients employees. In doing so, we made our products easy to use and more consistent with how employees engage with consumer technology and social media. 
If your company is an ADP client, I invite you to join the more than 8 million users of ADP's mobile app to experience this for yourself. 
We've leveraged our unique data set of 26 billion payroll records to introduce significant new data analytics capabilities. Since introducing ADP DataCloud just over 1 year ago, we now have more than 2,500 clients using this solution to generate actionable insights that help address workforce productivity, contribute to talent development and assist with employee retention. 
We've expanded our capabilities geographically and can now meet the payroll processing and compliance needs of companies with operation in more than 110 countries and territories, which is a key differentiator in our industry. 
And we met the challenges presented by the implementation of the Affordable Care Act in the U.S. With strong demand for our ACA solutions, we made investments in operational resources and successfully helped more than 25,000 clients to process more than 10 million Form 1095-Cs, the most significant new employee tax form introduced by the IRS since the W2. 
As we've discussed, we believe our investments to innovate and simplify our portfolio are essential for our long-term success. We believe our strategic platforms now deliver best-in-class HCM capabilities in each of the markets they serve, and we've seen solid retention rates from clients on our strategic platforms. Therefore, continuing to upgrade lines to
continuing to upgrade clients to our modern cloud solutions remains a critical area of focus for us and is the right thing to do for our clients. 
Today, all of our Small Business clients are on the RUN transfer platform. And during the fourth quarter, we increased the pace of our client migrations in the mid-market, and now have about 49,000 clients in our latest versions of Workforce Now. 
With 2/3 of this base now upgraded, we expect the balance of our Workforce Now clients to be transitioned to the current platform by the end of fiscal '17. 
As we continue to move clients on to our strategic platforms and have more clients engaging ADP for multiple services across the HCM spectrum, we are embarking on a path to simply by our service model for our associates and our clients. 
Over the past several years, our technology platforms have evolved to meet the dynamic needs of our clients who are choosing to engage in a more comprehensive way with their HCM providers. 
As a result of this shift, a new approach to service is essential to support the HCM companies that we've become and extend our leadership in this growing market, and am therefore, excited to tell you about a service initiative we are kicking off in fiscal 2017. 
This new initiative is designed to better align our service organization to work across additional lines, leverage best-in-class service tools and processes and establish teams with expertise across the HCM spectrum. We believe this will enhance the client experience and at the same time, allow us to better transfer knowledge amongst the service teams and offer robust career opportunities within the service organization, all of which benefits our clients and our service yields. 
As we begin to build out this new service model, we believe there's a benefit to be gained by co-locating certain U.S. service capabilities at existing and new ADP locations in the U.S. that have the scale to support this strategy. 
We have had positive experiences creating centers like these at sites such as El Paso, Texas, Augusta, Georgia, among other places. We recently selected Norfolk, Virginia and Macon, Florida, near Orlando, as our next 2 locations and has started building cross functional service teams at both sites. We will announce a third new site in the Western part of the U.S. later this year. 
As part of this initiative, we will focus on building service capabilities within these and our existing locations, while streamlining our geographic footprint. 
In connection with these efforts, ADP will be making certain investments in fiscal 2017, which are expected to put some pressure on our margin expansion goals for the year.  Jan will provide more detail when he reviews fiscal 2017 outlook. However, we do expect our margin expansion this fiscal 2017 to be lower than our long-term goal of 50 to 75 basis points as we make these important investments. 
Now I'd spend a few moments on retention. During the fourth quarter, we experienced a retention decline of 80 basis points, and for the full fiscal year, retention declined about 1 point to 19.5%. 
Similar to previous quarters, we continue to see a concentration of losses from clients who are still on legacy technology and while we have seen some of the benefits from investments we've made in service during the early part of fiscal 2016, we continue to experience variability in our retention metrics. 
In closing, fiscal 2016 was an exciting and challenging year for ADP. We achieved strong revenue growth, driven by sales of additional HCM modules to support clients with a new ACA requirements. We've invested implementation and operational resources to support this revenue growth, while still delivering solid margin expansion. And we did this while remaining consistent with our commitment to shareholder-friendly actions. 
During fiscal 2016, we returned about $2.1 billion in cash through dividends and share repurchases and increased our dividend for the 41st consecutive year. 
I'm confident that as we successfully execute against our strategy, we'll continue to drive results for our clients, our associates and our shareholders. 
And with that, I'll turn over the call to Jan who will review our fiscal 2016 financials and share our fiscal 2017 outlook.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you very much, Carlos, and good morning, everyone. During the fourth quarter, we took a severance charge of $48 million that was related to a broad-based workforce optimization effort. Certain non-GAAP measures in my commentary to follow excludes
componenttext:
Thank you very much, Carlos, and good morning, everyone. 
During the fourth quarter, we took a severance charge of $48 million that was related to a broad-based workforce optimization effort. Certain non-GAAP measures in my commentary to follow excludes the impact of this charge as well as certain other onetime items recognized earlier in the fiscal year. A reconciliation of these non-GAAP measures can be found in this morning's press release and in the supplemental charts of our Investor Relations website. 
As Carlos mentioned, fiscal year 2016 was a successful year for ADP. New business bookings grew 12% to $1.75 billion sold. Revenues grew 7% to $11.7 billion. Excluding the impacts of foreign currency translation, revenues grew 8% for the year. 
On a reported basis, net earnings grew 8% and diluted earnings per share grew 12%. Adjusted earnings before interest and taxes or adjusted EBIT grew 10% or 11% on a constant dollar basis. 
For the year, adjusted EBIT margin expanded 60 basis from the 18.8% in fiscal year 2015. I'm pleased with this solid margin expansion, which includes the impact of investments in operational resources that were made during the fiscal year as we supported our clients through the first year of the ACA related reporting requirements. Adjusted diluted earnings per share grew 13% to $3.26, reflecting a lower effective tax rate and fewer shares of outstanding compared with a year ago. 
In addition to delivering this solid operating performance, we have paid more than $900 million in dividends and returned about $1.2 billion through share repurchases for fiscal year 2016. 
During the fourth quarter, ADP returned $100 million to shareholders through share repurchases, which was at a reduced pace compared with prior quarters. Market conditions were not a factor in our long-standing commitment to returning cash to our shareholders remains unchanged. 
So now for a discussion of our segment results. i Our Employer Services segment, revenues grew 5% for the year or 6% at constant dollar basis. This growth was driven by additions to new recurring revenues during the fiscal year from strong new business bookings sold. As Carlos discussed, client revenue retention decreased 80 basis points in the fourth quarter. And for the year, revenue retention declined about 1 point to 19.5%. 
Our same-store pays per control in the U.S. grew 2.5% for the fiscal year. Average client fund balance grew 3% for the year or 4% on constant dollar basis. This growth was slower than prior years, primarily related to the declines of state unemployment insurance collections as a result of an improving labor market in the U.S. 
This, in combination with the impact on client losses experienced into the year, has put added pressure on the client funds balance growth. 
Our business outside of North America continues to perform well despite an uncertain global environment. This performance is driven by continued strong demand for our multinational solutions, which served businesses of all sizes and are now the largest contributor to our sales outside of North America. 
Employer Services segment margin increased about 60 basis points for the fiscal year. This increase was driven by reduced selling expenses in the fourth quarter compared to last year's fourth quarter, partially offset by the negative impact of planned investments made throughout the year to support our clients with the first year of ACA compliance. 
the PEO had a successful year, posting revenue growth of 16% and average worksite employee growth of 13%. 
Let me make a few comments about fourth quarter revenue growth in the PEO, which trended lower at 13% growth compared with the previous 3 quarters in fiscal year 2016. 
This revenue growth deceleration was based on 2 factors. First, regarding our gross revenues which include pass-throughs, our clients experienced a favorable impact from lower health care renewal premiums during our fourth quarter, which contributed to a lower relative growth in our pass-through revenues. 
Second, in the fourth quarter, we noticed some variability in the timing of payrolls run by our clients. This type of timing variability has occurred in the past and should not be viewed as an indicator of any underlying change in the fundamentals of the business. We remain pleased with the performance of our PEO, which have strong worksite employee growth of 13% and we are happy to see that the PEO also delivered strong margin expansion of approximately 70 basis points for fiscal year 2016, which was primarily driven by operating and selling efficiencies from increased productivity. 
This is solid overall performance for fiscal year 2016 with strong new business bookings yielding healthy revenue growth and solid margin expansion despite the additional investments we've made during the year. I'm pleased with our results and will now take you through our expectations for fiscal year 2017. 
As Carlos mentioned, for fiscal year 2017, we're  expecting new business bookings growth of 4% to 6% from $1.75 billion sold in fiscal year 2016. We anticipate total revenue growth of 7% to 9% for the year, which is not expected to be significantly impacted by foreign currency translation based on current rates. This forecast assumes 4% to 5% revenue growth in the Employer Services segment and growth in pays per control of 2.5%. Revenue growth for the PEO is expected to be 14% to 16%. 
ADP's adjusted EBIT margin is expected to expand 25 to 50 basis points from the 19.5% in fiscal year 2016, which is below our goal of 50 to 75 basis points of margin expansion over the longer run. We are still committed to this margin improvement goal over the longer term, but as Carlos mentioned, we are making investments in fiscal year 2017 to align our service model and support of our technology strategy. We expect this operational investments will put about 20 basis points of pressure on our fiscal year 2017 margins. And as a result of these buildout of the new facilities, total expenditures capital expenditures for fiscal year 2017 are expected to be about $250 million. 
In addition to these investments, we also anticipate certain onetime charges of $100 million to $125 million throughout fiscal year 2018. 
Of this, $45 million is expected to be incurred during the first quarter of fiscal year 2017 and $45 million in the latter part of the year with the remainder expected in fiscal year 2018. These charges are excluded from our fiscal year 2017 forecast for adjusted EBIT margin expansion and from our adjusted diluted earnings per share forecast. A reconciliation of these metrics can be found in this morning's press release and in the supplemental slides on our investor relations website. 
On a segment level, we anticipate pretax margin expansion of about 50 basis points for Employer Services and 50 to 75 basis points of margin expansion in the PEO. 
On a reported basis, diluted earnings per share is expected to grow 6% to 8% compared with the $3.25 in fiscal year 2015. Adjusted diluted earnings per share is expected to grow at 10% to 12% from the adjusted $3.26 in fiscal year 2016 and contemplates an adjusted effective tax rate of 33.3%, consistent with the 33.3% at fiscal year 2016. 
In accordance with our continued shareholder-friendly actions and our intention to return excess cash to shareholders, our earnings per share forecast assumes that access cash of $1.0 billion to $1.4 billion will be returned via share repurchases during the fiscal year 2017. This forecasted range includes anticipated share repurchases requires to offset employee benefit plan issuance and the timing of these share repurchases is dependent upon market conditions. 
So with that, I will take you through our forecast for the client funds extended investment strategy. First, a reminder that the objectives of our investment strategy remain the safety, liquidity and diversification of our assets. 
As of the end of the fiscal year, approximately 80% of our fixed income portfolio was invested in AAA and AA rated securities. In a typical year, our strategy results in about 15% to 20% or our fixed income investments maturing and this year, we expect a percentage of maturities will be closer to the lower end of this range. We continue to base the interest assumptions in our forecast on the Fed Funds' future contracts for the client short and corporate cash portfolios and forward yield curve of the 3.5- and 5-year U.S. government agency forward yield curves for the client and corporate extended and decline loan portfolios, respectively. 
And as we do not believe it is possible to accurately predict future interest rates, the shape of the yield curve and the new bond issuance behavior of corporate and other issuers. 
For fiscal year 2017, we anticipate growth in the average client funds balances of 2% to 4% from the $22.4 billion in fiscal year 2016. 
We anticipate that the yield of decline fund portfolio will remain about flat at 1.7% compared with fiscal year 2016. 
These factors are expected to result in an increase of up to $5 million decline fund interest revenue. The total contribution from the client funds extended investment strategy is expected to be about flat to fiscal year 2016. 
The detail of this forecast is available in the supplemental slides on our website. 
And before we take your questions, I wanted to let you know that Sara will be taking a new role within ADP finance as a CFO of one of our business units. want to thank Sara for her contributions, leading our Investor Relations program and welcome our new head of Investor Relations, Kristin, who was recently -- who h as recently led ADP's global accounting team. 
So with that, I will turn it over to the operator to take your questions.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] we'll take our first question from the line of James Schneider from Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] we'll take our first question from the line of James Schneider from Goldman Sachs.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was wondering if you could maybe give us an update on the migrations in the mid-market segment. I think you said 45,000 had already migrated. It sounds like maybe that's under 40,000 clients ago. Can you maybe talk about any changes you're seeing in ter
componenttext: I was wondering if you could maybe give us an update on the migrations in the mid-market segment. I think you said 45,000 had already migrated. It sounds like maybe that's under 40,000 clients ago. Can you maybe talk about any changes you're seeing in terms of as you make those migrations, where you're seeing any kind of additional client losses? And maybe you could just talk about the pace of migrations over the course of fiscal '17, where that can be back or front half loaded or just ratable over the course of the year?

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. I think the number was really 49,000 that have been migrated and I think we have about 25,000 to go. In terms of the other question, we did have some time to kind of reset how we were doing migrations and the pace also based on -- I mentioned that t
componenttext: Sure. I think the number was really 49,000 that have been migrated and I think we have about 25,000 to go. In terms of the other question, we did have some time to kind of reset how we were doing migrations and the pace also based on -- I mentioned that there were 3 factors that I think impacted our retention back over the last 3 quarters, and we think one of them was the pace of migrations and also the execution around migration. So a lot of work was done during what we call our year-end blackout because we really prefer not to do migrations anyway in the call it November to January, February time frame because there's a many things going on at the calendar year in a typical HCM payroll company. And so that gives a little bit of time for those folks to focus kind of stabilizing that organization and rethinking what the proper pace is and to put in perspective, we migrated approximately 4,000 clients during the quarter. And when we experienced challenges with some of the migrations, we were up as high as 7,000 in a quarter. This is back in the beginning of this fiscal year. So hopefully that gives you a little bit of color. And I think the overall comment is clearly, I think our competitors are fishing in those waters because we see them in the numbers in terms of our losses being concentrated in our legacy platforms, and we're trying to reduce the size of the fishing pond so there's still some variability there in the retention, but I think we've gotten better at how we're doing the migrations and I think our pace is more manageable and I think easier for us to control at this point.

componenttext: Sure, I'll let maybe Jan talk a little bit about the math. But I think that it does -- the math, I think does kind of work within may be 0.5 points to 1 point one way or the other depending on your perspective because we don't provide exact numbers. But we want to reiterate that we had strong growth in new business bookings this year, excluding ACA and then mathematically with that [indiscernible] grow over for next year because -- I think, we previously said or will say today that we don't expect the same level of new business bookings from ACA since we've already sold half of our addressable market even if we assume that we sell half of the remaining half next year, that creates a mathematical grow over issue for us. So I'll let maybe Jan comment on a math. But I think the message you'll hear from us is we believe over the course of the 3 years, as you can imagine, we look very carefully about the sales' strength coming from core operations, is a coming from additional business, is it coming from ACA, and we feel pretty good on a 3-year compounded basis about where our new business bookings growth is right now.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, thank you, Carlos. And there are 2 different methods you can look at this. You could exclude the ACA impact on all 3 years and look at the underlying growth of the rest of our new business bookings. And we would be delivering exactly what we have sai
componenttext: Yes, thank you, Carlos. And there are 2 different methods you can look at this. You could exclude the ACA impact on all 3 years and look at the underlying growth of the rest of our new business bookings. And we would be delivering exactly what we have said our in line with our long-term growth expectations of 8% to 10% over those 3 years, and you can also look at, is the decline driven by slowing of ACA sales in fiscal year '17 and that is yes, because we have addressed already half of our business opportunity in the first year, and we don't expect to close -- cover 100% of the sales opportunity in fiscal year '17. So we have to made assumptions on that. And so both are in line within a percentage points plus minus. So this is for government work and estimate that future impact.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think just more government work, again, these are not the right numbers, but mathematically, if you take 4% out of the 12%, that gives you 8%. And if you add 4% to the of 4% to 6%, you get back to 8% to 9%,  and you're still within the 8% range, right?
componenttext: I think just more government work, again, these are not the right numbers, but mathematically, if you take 4% out of the 12%, that gives you 8%. And if you add 4% to the of 4% to 6%, you get back to 8% to 9%,  and you're still within the 8% range, right? It can be so simplistic, but I think that's really the way the math works.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think that the -- yes, revenue growth has been accelerating for the last 5 years and I think some of that, obviously, is driven by the economy in terms of economy rebounded I think we had some help in pays per control and the number of other factors and
componenttext: I think that the -- yes, revenue growth has been accelerating for the last 5 years and I think some of that, obviously, is driven by the economy in terms of economy rebounded I think we had some help in pays per control and the number of other factors and just the strong new business bookings growth has created a bigger gap between our starts we call our starts on a losses and I think that has contributed to this accelerating growth in Employer Services. I think you're right that the losses that we experienced this year obviously have an effect this year, and they have an effect on the following year as well. But again, back to kind of simplistic math for government work, I think we're  probably, plus or minus half a point in terms of ES revenue growth. So maybe some of that is rounding, but we don't feel any weakness, I guess, to be clear and the ACA revenues, Jan probably has the exact number. That clearly provided lift in our new business bookings and thus, provide lift to revenue and also presents somewhat of a grow over. It's not as pronounced as grow over because it's a revenue number versus the new business bookings number, but it does have the same impact. But we feel -- like where we are right now Employer Services feels like a pretty good place in terms of trend, in terms of trajectory as well.

componenttext: We don't provide, really, the precise revenue numbers, but it is kind of a little bit above that. In the hundred plus million dollar range of ACA impact to ADP.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Bryan Keane from Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Bryan Keane from Deutsche Bank.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Ashish Sabadra calling on behalf of Bryan Keane. Just a follow up question on retention. So last quarter, you had mentioned you're taking some steps that are improving the service capability which you some more confidence around retention, but we
componenttext: This is Ashish Sabadra calling on behalf of Bryan Keane. Just a follow up question on retention. So last quarter, you had mentioned you're taking some steps that are improving the service capability which you some more confidence around retention, but we still saw the retention go or decline. Now my question was when you think about the mid-market customer base, you still have 25,000 customers remaining, which are going to be migrated over the next 4 quarters and normally you don't do the migration in November, December, which would imply like around north of 6,000 customers being migrated every quarter versus 4,000 that you signed the last quarter. So with this elevated level of migration, how should we think about retention going forward? Could we see retention get worse before it starts to get better? So any clarity that you could provide on the retention front, that would be helpful.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, it's a good question, it's a fair question. I think your math is actually very close. The only thing I would add to that math is you do have to apply a retention or a loss factor to that 25,000 itself. Over the course of 12 months, we naturally -- e
componenttext: Sure, it's a good question, it's a fair question. I think your math is actually very close. The only thing I would add to that math is you do have to apply a retention or a loss factor to that 25,000 itself. Over the course of 12 months, we naturally -- even if we weren't migrating, we'd lose -- call it, 10% of those clients. It might be a little bit higher than that just because the legacy type clients so the absolute number that you're starting with, that you had to divide over 4 quarters is a little bit smaller, but you're in the right ballpark. It's probably around 5,000-or-so clients that will be migrated for quarter. We feel pretty comfortable with the pace given the infrastructure that we've created, the process we have for migrations. In terms of additional color, as you're  pointing out, the results didn't cooperate with our desires and with our intentions and in part, that's because our retention is a reflection of the overall company's results and there's variability of a lot of other businesses, so I wouldn't read too it even though we still have a concentration of our retentions issues in the mid-market, and they have been for this fiscal year. There is another $8 billion to $9 billion of revenue in ADP that also has experienced variability in retention. But having said that, to give you specifics around why our confidence level was high that things would get better and why we still remains high, we have a number of -- in specifically, the mid-market issues that we were experiencing with regard to retention, we have a lot of metric as you can imagine that we look at that are leading indicators versus retention, which is a lagging indicator. For example, the speed to answer phone calls, the number of cases that are unresolved in a backlog, there's just -- we have a number of escalations in terms of people escalating client service issues. And the metrics are most of the metrics in the mid-market regarding service experience our clients are even back-to-back they were prior to our retention issues or in some cases, better. And so we feel confident that you have some kind of a lag in the sense that some clients may have already been in process due to a poor service experience at looking at alternative and the fact that there are other parts of ADP that have variability in retention as well, notwithstanding all those things, I think my confidence in the improvements in service stability and service experience in the mid-market remained quite high actually.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And if add a more technical comment relative to our losses that we see over the fiscal year, we have cyclicality in our loss volumes, and so year-end calendar year-end on the third quarter for us, fiscal year are traditionally higher loss months and the f
componenttext: And if add a more technical comment relative to our losses that we see over the fiscal year, we have cyclicality in our loss volumes, and so year-end calendar year-end on the third quarter for us, fiscal year are traditionally higher loss months and the fourth quarter month is a lower loss month. So hence, the candy variability in the quarterly shift of the retention numbers in this case back to a relatively low loss volume that we typically experience in the fourth quarter. So my general council would be to observe those retention changes that we report, but not to get overly analytical and mathematical quarter-by-quarter. It is a better indicator to think about basically our retention number of 100 basis points decline so for the fiscal year, we're aiming to be better. We don't guide to retention, but as you might imagine as a company, we clearly have aspirations to improve.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of David Grossman from Stifel Financial.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of David Grossman from Stifel Financial.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wonder if I can ask a quick question about the margin guidance. So if you could give us some good color on what the headwinds were going to be in fiscal '17. But if I understood you right, there's about 20 basis points of incremental headwinds over and
componenttext: I wonder if I can ask a quick question about the margin guidance. So if you could give us some good color on what the headwinds were going to be in fiscal '17. But if I understood you right, there's about 20 basis points of incremental headwinds over and above which you're isolating as nonrecurring. Perhaps you could give us a little bit more insight into what those incremental charges are. When you bundle everything together, as you come out of fiscal '17, how should we look at how the model has changed and how the leverage in the model changes beyond fiscal '17?

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So as we described, our initiative is really to create more concentrated centers of excellence in strategic locations, and we indicate basically 5 big cities that we're doing. So as a consequence, approximately 5% of our employee population is going to be
componenttext: So as we described, our initiative is really to create more concentrated centers of excellence in strategic locations, and we indicate basically 5 big cities that we're doing. So as a consequence, approximately 5% of our employee population is going to be transferring or moving, the work will be moving and impacting [indiscernible] our associates population in this fiscal year. And there are costs that are related to this, which we are non-GAAP-ing, which are related in essence to employee cost to facilitate the transfer of the work. That is basically included in the 20 basis points in our guidance. We clearly hope that the outcome of this service alignment initiative is multi-folded. I believe strongly it will enhance our service value proposition because we're going to have larger centers with bigger capabilities, leveraging ADP's strengths in compliance and service and offering a better value proposition to our clients, which is the most exciting part for the service alignment initiative. Hopefully resulting in better competitiveness and high retention rates and also as you can see, these centers are located in geographies of the U.S. that offer certain advantages relative to the cost that where they operate. So there should be in the longer run also contribution to our margins. We're a little bit hesitant to specify this for '18 because the initiative will actually bleed over into fiscal year '18. We mentioned, in particular, a center [indiscernible] West is going to come on later in '17 and will bleed over '18. So '18 will have still have some impact. But we are clearly hoping that it will guarantee basically that we can fulfill our commitment to the 50 to 75 basis points of margin expansion in the long run. So this is an important supporting initiative for that.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And David, I think to be -- I think you're right the 20 basis points above what we've put in the "non-GAAP numbers." And I think that's just frictional cost. They are identified. We know what those costs are, and they are cost that if not appropriate to b
componenttext: And David, I think to be -- I think you're right the 20 basis points above what we've put in the "non-GAAP numbers." And I think that's just frictional cost. They are identified. We know what those costs are, and they are cost that if not appropriate to bucket into the non-GAAP charges, I guess, is the best way to put it. I'm not obviously, the accountant, but I think your math is or your comment was [indiscernible]. So that's the -- when we provided that color to give you more information to be able to come up with what you might think might be the longer-term potential performance of the company, which as Jan said, we're optimistic about. I think we're doing this things -- really, there's two things we're always focused on: Service experience, the client experience from our service organization and implementation and just the operations of the organizational raw and our competitiveness and our efficiency. And this is a -- I would call this, a large initiative and a complex initiative that hopefully is coming across with the significant that it should, and it's multi-year.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And can I ask just one follow up on just the CapEx comment as well? So it sounds like CapEx is over $200 million related to this. So is there anything we should think differently about the year-over-year growth in free cash flow in fiscal '17?
componenttext: And can I ask just one follow up on just the CapEx comment as well? So it sounds like CapEx is over $200 million related to this. So is there anything we should think differently about the year-over-year growth in free cash flow in fiscal '17?

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I'll let -- maybe Jan can comment a little more on the CapEx. So we weren't implying that the entire CapEx because of this initiative. We have normal ongoing CapEx. It's just trending higher than it has historically so we want to make sure that we put
componenttext: So I'll let -- maybe Jan can comment a little more on the CapEx. So we weren't implying that the entire CapEx because of this initiative. We have normal ongoing CapEx. It's just trending higher than it has historically so we want to make sure that we put that out there. But I do want to comment besides Jan giving you the specifics on the numbers that we are investing in this company, so this company has a an industry that has positive global dynamic in terms of growth. We just saw with ACA in the U.S. We're going to see it with FLSA and the EEOC equity pay rules, and we're seeing the same thing in other countries. And so this company has opportunity, and we intend to invest in order to seize those opportunities. And so I think what you seeing is our investment in CapEx and frankly, also our investment in capitalized software, which we disclosed, but it's not something that we necessarily always focus on are all trending higher. And we take the deployment of capital very, very seriously, as you know, but people should not mistake what our actions are for anything other than optimism about the future and the potential for a new investments at of incremental return for our shareholders over the long term.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I only have 2 comments to add is so it is a temporarily higher capital expenditure rate and the increase is to the very largest amount driven by investments in to all real estate project to get these facilities up and going and related investments for thi
componenttext: I only have 2 comments to add is so it is a temporarily higher capital expenditure rate and the increase is to the very largest amount driven by investments in to all real estate project to get these facilities up and going and related investments for this initiative. And secondly, I'd like also to remind you that ADP has pursued over the last couple of years a growth strategy that is more focused on our organic growth capabilities, focusing on investments into our own product set and focusing in this initiative on enhancing and developing additional market leader and service capabilities. So I think it's right in line with how the strategy has worked for ADP, and it's really quite an exciting moment for ADP.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Rick Eskelsen from Wells Fargo.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Rick Eskelsen from Wells Fargo.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Wonder if you could go back on the new service initiative. Just to kind up see if you could tie into the investments that you've made earlier in the delivery side. Sort what kind of informed this? How related or not was it to the service delivery issues a
componenttext: Wonder if you could go back on the new service initiative. Just to kind up see if you could tie into the investments that you've made earlier in the delivery side. Sort what kind of informed this? How related or not was it to the service delivery issues and investments that you had earlier? And just tie those 2 together.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I'll make a comment and Jan, I think, can ad. I really appreciate the question because they are actually quite separate topics. And so the service delivery issues that we experience for concentrated in a particular part of our business in the mid-marke
componenttext: So I'll make a comment and Jan, I think, can ad. I really appreciate the question because they are actually quite separate topics. And so the service delivery issues that we experience for concentrated in a particular part of our business in the mid-market, and they were execution-related. And I think what we're talking about in terms of new service element initiative is a broad strategic objective across the entire company. It's partly driven by the fact that the industry has evolved and I think the clients need to evolve and the product have it both. And so as an example, 10 years ago, having 3 or 4 different products that were serviced differently and different databases was not an issue. Our platforms know are single database integrated solutions that provide an HCM solution if the way -- if the client wants to buy it that way in a comprehensive and seamless way. The service model had not moved in the same direction. And I think that this initiative really intended to have our service implementation really aligned with the way the market is going, the way buyers are buying and the way clients want to be serviced. So we've done similar things that our sales organization where that also requires that our sales force be trained and equipped to be able to sell in a new environment. So our belief is that now we will have our products, our service and our distribution all aligned.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I think this is probably the best way to connect our focus on creating competitive technology platforms that our cloud-based and integrated as a prerequisite to create the integrated service models. So we have made really A, great progress with this s
componenttext: And I think this is probably the best way to connect our focus on creating competitive technology platforms that our cloud-based and integrated as a prerequisite to create the integrated service models. So we have made really A, great progress with this strategic platforms, but B, also migrated now a large numbers of clients on to these platforms so it really does make good sense at this point in time to launch the service alignment initiative. And as you might imagine, we did have -- we have tested the service models and components of our organization at smaller scale, and we have seen great results out of those pilots.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And if I can just quickly follow up, Jan, on the comment you made earlier about have you been making more organic investments. Has anything changed just in general in terms of your portfolio shaping, any sort of divestitures, smaller ones to come? And how
componenttext: And if I can just quickly follow up, Jan, on the comment you made earlier about have you been making more organic investments. Has anything changed just in general in terms of your portfolio shaping, any sort of divestitures, smaller ones to come? And how are you approaching M&A currently?

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Now, I think our principle stand on M&A has not changed. We have a very solid balance sheet, we have the capital to invest in the industry, and we continue to value the opportunities, but we evaluate M&A opportunities in light of our strategic priorities,
componenttext: Now, I think our principle stand on M&A has not changed. We have a very solid balance sheet, we have the capital to invest in the industry, and we continue to value the opportunities, but we evaluate M&A opportunities in light of our strategic priorities, which is -- which are focused at this point of time on reduction in complexity and aligning and focus on our client needs so any acquisitions that support that drive we will actively and aggressively pursue. But it has played out over the last 3 years to a more organic growth pattern that has seen great results. And so I think that stand's stays the same. I would not expect any dramatic shift in our added towards M&A from what you have seen in the last 3 years. And relative to divestitures and adjusting the portfolio, I think the large portfolio alignment initiatives that have happened with the spin-off of CDK and I think our larger the last large divestiture was a vast empty. There will be here and there smaller types of things as we can continually to evaluate the performance of our product portfolio. And if we see opportunities enhance shareholder value, we will pursue it as we have done so in the past. But it's really an essence, I would anticipate fiscal year '17 to run under the same guidepost as in the last 3 years.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I think that, I think Jan's actually right in all those points. And I would just add that back to the discussion about the capital and all the seriousness, which we take capital deployment. We do have a strong balance sheet, so we have capital that we
componenttext: And I think that, I think Jan's actually right in all those points. And I would just add that back to the discussion about the capital and all the seriousness, which we take capital deployment. We do have a strong balance sheet, so we have capital that we can deploy. But as Jan said, conceptually, it's something really fit into our technology road map and accelerated our progress, we'd use our capital, but we're not going to use our capital to have something that for lack of a better term, fits next to everything else that it so just to be able to beat the integrated rapidly and seamlessly into what we already are pursuing to move our product strategy. It's a little bit of a departure from call it, 6, 7 years ago when it was really more about leveraging our distribution and adding capabilities and products without as much necessarily regard to how they fit tightly into the technology road map. And that's really nothing so much a change in strategy. It's a change in market the way people want to buy and the way products behave, which makes it very, very important to have tight alignment and seamlessness in your products. And then the just actual comment I'll make to Jan's point is because we have capital, if something accelerated our progress, we would do it no different than we're doing some of these internal organic things that we're investing in to accelerate our progress. So there's an external opportunity to use or capital, we would. But the fact is over the last couple of years, when you look at the balance of the capital deployment, Jan and I have this discussion all the time, they're consciously avoided doing acquisitions. It's just been hard to find one that makes sense and fit in what we're doing in terms of our strategy. But net-net, when you get down to it, we're spending, call it $300 million to $400 million less on acquisitions, and we're spending more on things like internally developed products, capital expenditures and the investments that we're talking about for fiscal year '17. So it wasn't necessarily planned that way, but it just so happens that we're not necessarily deploying any more capital, but we're just deploying it in a slightly different way. But we do retain the right to deploy capital towards acquisitions as well.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Mark Marcon from Baird.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Mark Marcon from Baird.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just wondering if you could just add a little more color in terms of the service realignment, in terms of how clients may end up being serviced. Is it -- is there going to be a transition to like a dedicated service wrap for the mid-market? What did you s
componenttext: Just wondering if you could just add a little more color in terms of the service realignment, in terms of how clients may end up being serviced. Is it -- is there going to be a transition to like a dedicated service wrap for the mid-market? What did you see out of the pilot studies? And what's the reaction internally with some of the service providers in terms of potentially geographically relocating?

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's a great question. We'll give you a little bit of color, and it may be Jan can add in terms of what he's hearing out in the field. So it's interesting the term dedicated reps because we do have parts of our business obviously in the an upmarket and na
componenttext: It's a great question. We'll give you a little bit of color, and it may be Jan can add in terms of what he's hearing out in the field. So it's interesting the term dedicated reps because we do have parts of our business obviously in the an upmarket and national accounts where we have very specific people service specific clients and then when you get into the Small Business market, we tend to have a model where the execution and the delivery is very important, but the person that you reach isn't as important. We believe that's the right model. We believe our retention rates and our growth in the Small Business market prove that our model works as long as you execute well. And would also argue that in today's world, having a dedicated rep works who 8 hours a day might not be the best service model for a small company or any other company. So we prefer to focus on how and what's the best way to deliver the best service to the client in the way they want it delivered. And it varies from Small Business, up to the upmarket in terms of where you need a dedicated person or not. But I would encourage you to kind of visualize the service realignment as being more around teams rather than dedicated people. So having alignment around teams. So as an example, given the attach rates that we've discussed over multiple quarters that we're experiencing now in the mid-market and in the upmarket around additional HCM modules, in other words, clients are rarely buying just payroll by itself or just benefits demonstration by itself. So this business model really is intended to be able to provide a group of people or a team of people who work together who are co-located and can deliver service across the entire HCM spectrum. That obviously requires some cross-training, but also some ability for people who have special skills to be available and close to people who need to support our clients on a multiple number of issues. So we have reasonable amount of experience and experimenting with what we call intact teams or with co-located teams. And we feel pretty good about the results when it comes to retention, when it comes to client. And by the way, in our business, when you have those 2 things, margin follows. So this is primarily led by quality and experience for the client and also by the way, opportunity for our associates. So what we have found also in some of our subscale locations has very, very limited mobility and opportunity for associates to progress from a career standpoint. And we now have a number of opportunities across our business for people to learn new things and to move in a different areas, whether it's time and attendance and payroll, benefits administration, talent management, we really run the whole gamut on HCM, and we have need to cross the entire business. And when we have people scattered across the entire country in small subscale locations, it just doesn't, I think, makes sense from a talent management standpoint for ourselves internally either. So on all those fronts, we think that this service alignment strategy makes sense.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Carlos mentioned most of the factors. I would add 2. We have seen a rise in our associate engagement scores as a consequence for those who work in those intact teams, and it reflects probably better of how in a modern team environment our associates want
componenttext: Carlos mentioned most of the factors. I would add 2. We have seen a rise in our associate engagement scores as a consequence for those who work in those intact teams, and it reflects probably better of how in a modern team environment our associates want to work. So that's really exciting for our associates as well. And I have one additional component that is strategic move on locations allows you to plan for is also a coordinated effort between our market segments, small. Medium and large. So I think we mentioned it in the call. So now we have co-location between those market segments and can be natural growth and exchange or best practices between the different platforms. And for some of the platforms, the back end is fairly similar. If you think about centers of excellence for our tax filing operations and so forth so it allows us also to create buckets of scale that are very hard to create in smaller locations. So it really, I believe, will transform of how are our associates be perceiving, A, the value of the job they're in and the job opportunities that they can reach in the future and allows us to deliver additional service capabilities to our clients, which is the strategic benefit that's leaping out of it.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Certainly, I think it makes a lot of sense. I applaud you for taking this long-term step. Can you talk also with regards to the expectations for new bookings growth, where you would expect to see the strongest growth in terms of which areas?
componenttext: Certainly, I think it makes a lot of sense. I applaud you for taking this long-term step. Can you talk also with regards to the expectations for new bookings growth, where you would expect to see the strongest growth in terms of which areas?

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'll take this right on. If you look at fiscal year '16, we have had actually a fairly balanced growth across the business. We had great performance early along all segments and continued strength in multinational, great performance, really, across a
componenttext: Yes, I'll take this right on. If you look at fiscal year '16, we have had actually a fairly balanced growth across the business. We had great performance early along all segments and continued strength in multinational, great performance, really, across all segments. So may be the only spot that has been a little bit harder was Europe as you might imagine and our best-of-breed solutions but that's is really more balanced like a good demand for multinational solutions. So when we look at the plan other than specific grow-over challenges that we have because ACA sales were concentrated in the mid-market and in the upmarket, if you take that out, it's really -- each of the business units continues with very good performance. And just as a reminder, it is -- was $1.75 billion of recurring revenue that the sales force generated for ADP and even if the growth is a few percentage points slower, it's kind of still a very significant number.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our last question for today will be coming from the line of Gary Bisbee from RBC.
componenttext: Our last question for today will be coming from the line of Gary Bisbee from RBC.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I wanted to go back to an earlier question just around the concept of revenue acceleration. So you had 2 years of above trend bookings, you got pays per control continuing to click along at a similar pace. You had a drag this year from selling the busi
componenttext: So I wanted to go back to an earlier question just around the concept of revenue acceleration. So you had 2 years of above trend bookings, you got pays per control continuing to click along at a similar pace. You had a drag this year from selling the business that was no longer be a drag in 2017 and retention was a drag, I guess, you're not saying specifically, but maybe still a drag, but it sounds like a lesser one potentially in 2017. So why don't -- -- you've already said the current year bookings don't do a lot to revenue. Why wouldn't we see some acceleration? Is it as simple as PEO you're calling for that to be slower? It just feels like there should be a bit better revenue growth from -- take you through all these moving parts.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. But I think if the math is how the math is going to work out between the starts that we have sold and the retention and there's certainly no change in how we have build out our business models over time. We did have a little bit of unusual revenue sk
componenttext: Yes. But I think if the math is how the math is going to work out between the starts that we have sold and the retention and there's certainly no change in how we have build out our business models over time. We did have a little bit of unusual revenue skewing that created more revenue acceleration, I guess, for this year and for next year, which contributed a little bit to the thing. But if you take that into account, there's really nothing that unusual in next year's revenue growth.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think all of the things you mentioned, it's important to acknowledge what you said. We do, again, even though we don't get specific guidance, we do expect less of a drag, for example, from retention because we expect thing to get better. We have so
componenttext: Yes, I think all of the things you mentioned, it's important to acknowledge what you said. We do, again, even though we don't get specific guidance, we do expect less of a drag, for example, from retention because we expect thing to get better. We have some metrics and some things underlying I think data that it gives us hope with these right because don't know for sure that, that will improve your math, the comments you made about new business bookings. So all those things are correct. I think I would just encourage you to maybe spend some time off line with us in terms of kind of the math and how the revenue works. One of the interesting things about this business, this is an incredibly stable and predictable business model. It's also very, very hard to move the numbers dramatically one way or the other over the course of 1 year. So over the course of 4, 5 years, we had double-digit new business bookings. And this year, we had a blip with retention, but retention has also been fairly stable. That's allowed us to accelerate our revenue growth by about 0.5 to 1 percentage point from call it, 5 years ago in Employer Services. The PEO, as you said, also happen to be a factor because it's growing faster and it's becoming a larger portion of the overall results so if it slows slightly that has an impact, too. So we'll spend the time to make sure that we do the math. But what I can tell you is you're right that this year if you exclude the impact of the divestiture or if you don't factor the divestiture in, we were close to 9% revenue growth. We're really proud of that. And next year, we're slightly below that because there's one day less because this year was a leap year, whatever the issues are in with a little bit of a drag still from -- even the retention is getting better, it's still not a good as it used to be. We still going to be pretty damn happy and pretty damn proud because we're going to be in, I think, still in the high end of our guidance from a revenue standpoint. And in this business, when you get into that range, given who are in terms of -- because we understand have a very keen insight into who we are as a company in terms of where we want to be in terms of growth rates, the margin improvement, the balance of those things, I think we're satisfied with that outcome. It obviously makes it easier as you pick up additional revenue growth because of the nice leverage ability of our operating model, but that's part of why we're also doing some things about what we're doing around servicing limit because we know that we're really not I think satisfied with just the results that we have today. On the other hand, we're not going to sit here and tell you that we're trying to aim for 10%, 12%, 15% revenue growth. That's not really not who we are. So 7% to 9% is our long-term guidance for revenue growth with some margin improvement, with a healthy dividend. We share buyback, that's our model, that's what we're executing against and I'm proud of the organization, the results they've delivered this year and I think if we deliver the results that we put out there for next year, we're going to be just as proud of that as well.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: This allows me to make another pitch for our fantastic and very differentiated ACA product. There's actually far more than just sending out 1095 and [indiscernible] forms. It's really compliance service that we offer, that ongoing -- offers ongoing monito
componenttext: This allows me to make another pitch for our fantastic and very differentiated ACA product. There's actually far more than just sending out 1095 and [indiscernible] forms. It's really compliance service that we offer, that ongoing -- offers ongoing monitoring and assessment services for eligibility and affordability and also, which is really very differentiated in this market offers what we call notice management services at the back end to react to agency and exchange notices and keep the company in compliance for those. That's where the bulk of the fines can actually incur. So we build our clients on a per employee, per month basis. So the revenue stream is actually not concentrated on a specific form delivery, it's an annualized recurring revenues. So you should think about the revenues exactly the same way you think about the rest of ADP.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks. This is our 67th-year and where we've combined world-class operations with innovative products and services that meet the dynamic needs of our clients. This was never more evident than in 2016, and I'm proud of the success of our business in getti
componenttext:
Thanks. This is our 67th-year and where we've combined world-class operations with innovative products and services that meet the dynamic needs of our clients. This was never more evident than in 2016, and I'm proud of the success of our business in getting solutions to market to meet those needs of the clients. And if I can't gear my soapbox for a second. I mentioned previously that ADP's -- this is ADP's 41st consecutive year of paying and increasing our dividend. And the dividend aristocrat, ADP is one of just over 50 companies in the S&P 500 who have paid an increase of dividend for more than 25 years. 
Now with some of the things we're talking about for fiscal year '17, ADP's leaders and associates are making the investments to lay the foundation for ADP to join the dividend royals in 9 years, and that's a list of just 17 companies who have paid and increased their dividend for more than 50 years. Any student of business know that only the most durable and enduring icons of business make that list. 
This success is entirely attributable to the hard work and dedication of our associates who commit themselves every day to ensuring our clients' success. 
So to them and to all before them, I say thank you. And I thank you all for joining the call today and for your interest in ADP.

headline: Automatic Data Processing, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
